claim: Records by the Beatles are illegal in the UK.

supporting.text: The Beatles' music is widely available and legally sold in the UK, contradicting the claim that their records are illegal.

attacks.text: The Beatles' music is widely available and legally sold in the UK, contradicting the claim that their records are illegal.
Some Beatles records may contain uncleared samples or copyrighted material, making them technically illegal to distribute in certain cases.
Even if some samples are uncleared, the vast majority of Beatles records are fully licensed and legally distributed in the UK.
The claim might refer to a specific historical period when certain Beatles records were temporarily banned in the UK for controversial content.
Any temporary bans were lifted decades ago, and those records are now legally available in the UK.

supporting.text: The Beatles' catalog is protected under UK copyright law, allowing legal distribution and sale of their records.

attacks.text: The Beatles' catalog is protected under UK copyright law, allowing legal distribution and sale of their records.
Some Beatles records may contain unauthorized samples or uncleared copyrights, making their distribution illegal.
Copyright disputes are typically resolved before commercial release, making unauthorized samples rare in Beatles records.
Bootleg or counterfeit Beatles records are illegal in the UK despite copyright protection for official releases.
Bootlegs are a niche market and do not represent the legal status of the Beatles' official catalog.

supporting.text: No UK law or regulation prohibits the sale, possession, or distribution of Beatles records, making the claim false.

attacks.text: No UK law or regulation prohibits the sale, possession, or distribution of Beatles records, making the claim false.
Certain Beatles records containing controversial lyrics or samples might violate UK obscenity or copyright laws.
No Beatles record has ever been officially banned or deemed illegal under UK obscenity or copyright laws.
Private institutions or venues in the UK might ban Beatles records under their own policies, creating a de facto restriction.
Private bans do not equate to legal prohibition, and the original claim refers to UK law, not private policies.

supporting.text: The Beatles are a culturally celebrated band in the UK, and their music is frequently played on radio and streaming platforms without legal restrictions.

attacks.text: The Beatles are a culturally celebrated band in the UK, and their music is frequently played on radio and streaming platforms without legal restrictions.
Some Beatles songs have been banned or censored in the past due to controversial lyrics or content, suggesting partial restrictions.
The bans or censorships were temporary and context-specific, not reflective of a general illegality of their records in the UK.
Copyright disputes could theoretically restrict access to Beatles records if legal battles result in injunctions.
Copyright disputes are rare and typically resolved without widespread bans, maintaining general accessibility of Beatles music.
